comments.body: This can be simplified. Both Random and SystemRandom accept a seed value, in both cases the default value is None. So there is no need for a condition. The default value can be passed unconditionally

SystemRandom accepts the seed parameter, but it does not honor it.

```
>>> for i in range(3): print(SystemRandom('foo').randint(0, 100))
... 
10
93
46
>>> for i in range(3): print(Random('foo').randint(0, 100))
... 
89
89
89
>>>
```

Their implementations differ and I don't want to change the default behavior (by switching to weaker random generator).
Meh, it even is documented that SystemRandom ignores the seed. Sorry for the noise.
In the docs, i would make note that this expands 'LOCAL' vars and not remote ones, so users realize that using remote paths with this can lead to errors.
